headline: Fox News Poll: Vance moves into top spot in Ohio GOP Senate primary
sentences: Conducted April 20-24, 2022 under the joint direction of Beacon Research (D) and Shaw & Company Research (R), this Fox News Poll includes telephone interviews (landline and cellphone) with live interviewers among 906 Ohio Republican primary voters and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

In addition, undecided voters are less likely than those who are supporting a candidate to say it is extremely important to vote for someone who can win in November (37%), or that it is extremely important the candidate is a strong supporter of Trump (16%).

Vance has doubled in the Ohio Republican Senate primary race, catapulting him ahead of earlier frontrunners former Ohio Treasurer Josh Mandel and businessman Mike Gibbons -- although many voters remain undecided or uncertain about their vote.

"The race is obviously close, and this is clearly a case in which an endorsement has made a difference," says Republican pollster Daron Shaw, who conducts Fox News surveys with Democrat Chris Anderson.
"With support spread out among five candidates who are pretty similar in policy terms, the bump that comes with Trumps blessing is enough to jump Vance to the head of the pack."
Randomly selected from a statewide voter file of registered Ohio voters, respondents were screened to identify potential participants in the Republican primary elections.
In the governors race, incumbent Mike DeWine (43%) maintains a significant lead over former Congressman Jim Renacci (24%) and farmer and businessman Joe Blystone (19%).
Vances 5-point advantage is within the surveys margin of sampling error -- and the largest number of primary voters, 25%, remains undecided about their vote.
Vance is the top choice with the voters who prioritize winning in November (by 13 points) as well as those who want a strong Trump supporter (by 8 points).
Vance clearly gained an important bloc of voters from Trumps endorsement, but he may have already reaped all he can from that," says Anderson.
Undecided Senate voters give Vance the highest net favorable rating (+14), closely followed by Mandel (+12), Dolan (+11), and Gibbons (+8).
A 60% majority of Ohio GOP primary voters would like to see Trump run for president again, while a sizable 32% minority rejects that idea.
Texas Sen. Ted Cruz is backing Mandel, Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul endorsed Gibbons, and Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley is campaigning for Vance.

SEXUAL MISCONDUCT CONVICTION REACHED IN FIRST-EVER AIR FORCE TRIAL OF MAJOR GENERAL
Trump won Ohio by 8 points in both 2016 and 2020.
Seventy percent of DeWines backers feel certain they will vote for him compared to 64% for Renacci and 63% for Blystone.
However, many are unfamiliar with the candidates: 25% are unable to rate Vance, 31% Gibbons, 37% Timken, and 45% Dolan.
Forty-two percent of primary voters say that made them more supportive of Vance, while it made 23% less supportive.
Thats far more than the 27% who give the same weight to the candidate being a strong supporter of Trump.
Dolan (25%) leads among those who do not want to see Trump on the ballot again, with Vance (18%) second.
Fifty percent say a candidates electability will be extremely important in deciding their vote.
State Sen. Matt Dolan comes in at 11% (+4) and former Ohio GOP chair Jane Timken gets 6% (-3).
Thats according to a Fox News survey of Ohio voters participating in the May 3 GOP primary.
Moreover, half of those currently supporting a candidate say they could change their mind.
"Undecided voters might be looking at this race differently than those who have decided.
Vance receives the backing of 23% of primary voters, up 12 points since last month.
Still, compared to last month, DeWines support is down 7 points and Renaccis up 6.
He garners a net +29 favorable rating: 52% view him favorably vs. 23% unfavorably.
That puts him ahead of Dolan (+21), Mandel (+18), Gibbons (+15), and Timken (+4).
In his statement endorsing the author, Trump said, "It is all about winning!"
Vance (25%) and Mandel (22%) lead among those who want another Trump run.
Mandel gets 18% (down 2 points), while Gibbons stands at 13% (down 9).
Rob Portman, who has held office since 2011, endorsed Timken.
For another 27%, Trumps stamp of approval made no difference.
Mandel is the most known, as 15% cant give an opinion of him.
Former President Donald Trump endorsed Vance on April 15.
Fox News Victoria Balara contributed to this report.
Voters see Vance as the most likable.
Many Ohio GOP primary voters agree.
The contest appears fluid.
Support for author J.D.
Retiring Ohio Sen.
